title: People who have their shit together. How??
author: mordor_fire

comments.author: MSAPIOPsych
comments.body: Don't think about how long its going to take to get there. Just consistently do a bunch of small steps and make the daily routine steps better than the last time you did them even if its just hanging a broom neatly vs just throwing it in a closet. It is that one degree of change until you've suddenly come full circle.
comments.body_html: Don't think about how long its going to take to get there. Just consistently do a bunch of small steps and make the daily routine steps better than the last time you did them even if its just hanging a broom neatly vs just throwing it in a closet. It is that one degree of change until you've suddenly come full circle.

replies.author: JPL26
replies.body: This is so true. I was explaining this to a friend of mine whose having some ‘what do I do with my life’ questions and just always stalling. The small steps is so underrated, I feel like In today’s world, so many people try and take a short cut straight to an end goal, but forget the little things that create the journey.
replies.body_html: This is so true. I was explaining this to a friend of mine whose having some ‘what do I do with my life’ questions and just always stalling. The small steps is so underrated, I feel like In today’s world, so many people try and take a short cut straight to an end goal, but forget the little things that create the journey.

replies.author: KamikazeFox_
replies.body:
We live in a age of immediate gratification and it's starting to take away the journey. That process is fundamental to the learning process. 


If you were playing a really good RPG and started at max lvl in the open world,  you wouldn't know how to do shit. Ya, you got there quick, but have nothing to show for it. 

Small changes are vital in growth.
replies.body_html:
We live in a age of immediate gratification and it's starting to take away the journey. That process is fundamental to the learning process.

Small changes are vital in growth.

replies.author: HotHamburgerSandwich
replies.body: There's this guy named Simon Sinek who does these leadership lectures and you can find some on youtube. But a lot of what he talks about is how most people give up way to easy and are conditioned by social media to believe the things worth accomplishing in life should be conquered immediately without the work

But a lot of what he talks about is how most people give up way to easy and are conditioned by social media to believe the things worth accomplishing in life should be conquered immediately without the work

replies.body: I took your advice and prepped my lunch for work tomorrow. It’s gonna cut down at least 10-15 minutes from my morning nonsense lol

replies.body: I think that is really awesome
replies.body_html: I think that is really awesome

comments.author: rosenohr
comments.body:
I got a calendar and learned how to use it. It's obvious for an organized person how to use a calendar, but I wasn't one of those. Had notes, appointments, to do lists, etc strewn all over my desk, in my bag, in my head (of course those where the ones I forgot instantly).

Now I have a calendar. It goes where I go. It is the one place where I write down all my shit and I check it twice a day, first in the morning and then when I finish up work for the day.

Changed my life.

replies.body: My girlfriend loves her diary for keeping organised (like a planner thing, not a  ‘Dear diary’ type one).  A lot of successful business people use them so there must be something to it.

replies.author: creamdryerlint
replies.body: Yep. Having your shit together is 100% easier when you make a habit of journaling every day. It's hard to explain how impactful it is. When you journal, its a mode of thinking you just can't get any other way. You're able to widen and narrow your perspective in deliberate ways.
replies.body_html: Yep. Having your shit together is 100% easier when you make a habit of journaling every day. It's hard to explain how impactful it is. When you journal, its a mode of thinking you just can't get any other way. You're able to widen and narrow your perspective in deliberate ways.

replies.body: I did this in college too. It’s so important! Between working part time, a killer commute, class, and sleeping 8 hours a night, it made me budget my time for homework better. Solid 8 hours is so important! Good advice!
replies.body_html: I did this in college too. It’s so important! Between working part time, a killer commute, class, and sleeping 8 hours a night, it made me budget my time for homework better. Solid 8 hours is so important! Good advice!

Then, if I’m lucky enough to fall asleep before midnight ticks round I only sleep for a could hours and almost always end up awake by 3:33 am

replies.author: paulyvc26
replies.body: If it helps, I keep a diary and jott down all the things on my mind if I'm having trouble sleeping, only takes 15 mins. It's easier to fall asleep with a clear head. You have such a busy life that you don't get time to process things during the day so it happens at night when you want to sleep.

comments.author: Tank_Girl_Gritty_235
comments.body:
Not only is it OK to half ass something, don't beat yourself over quarter, eighth, or sixteenth assing something.
We're all pushed into adulthood with this idea that we have to be machines that churn out quality stuff 24/7. Have a daunting sink full of dishes? Wash one spoon. Next time you go in, wash one plate. Next time, a cup.
Clear one square foot of a cluttered room or one corner of a cluttered table. Set a timer and work on that project for five minutes. Not up for a full exercise? Walk up and down the block or circle your house. Stand in the yard or on the stoop for five minutes. It's enough for today. 
Don't spend time beating yourself up over not being able to do everything at once because it will keep you from doing anything at all.
comments.body_html: Not only is it OK to half ass something, don't beat yourself over quarter, eighth, or sixteenth assing something. We're all pushed into adulthood with this idea that we have to be machines that churn out quality stuff 24/7. Have a daunting sink full of dishes? Wash one spoon. Next time you go in, wash one plate. Walk up and down the block or circle your house. Stand in the yard or on the stoop for five minutes. It's enough for today. Don't spend time beating yourself up over not being able to do everything at once because it will keep you from doing anything at all.

replies.author: justletmebrowsepls
replies.body: I read a comment similar to this on a post about avoiding procrastination and I think it's an excellent thing to keep in mind. I would always be overwhelmed when looking at something I had to do or clean, but writing a few lines of an essay haphazardly or cleaning a few things quickly whittles down a once apparently daunting task.

replies.author: graaaaaasstastesbad
replies.body: Avoiding sugar is by far the hardest for me
replies.body_html: Avoiding sugar is by far the hardest for me

replies.author: at132pm
replies.body:
It’s tough to start if you’ve been eating added sugar (and stuff like high fructose corn syrup) your whole life.

It can also be a weird first couple weeks.  My thought processes actually started to change.  Went really sluggish for a couple days.

It is so worth it though.  Developed a much wider range of foods that I loved.  Things naturally tasted better after a few months.  Less inflammation throughout my body.  Sharper thoughts.  Less crashes and more energy overall.

The easiest way I found to start was to eat exceptionally clean and healthy for 3 days.  Nothing processed or fried or with sugar.  Mostly just greens.

3 days is short enough that anyone can do it, even though it’s still hard.  It’s long enough to make a difference though, not just in your mind, but your gut biome.

After that, add back in something you miss that you cut out, but make sure you don’t add any sugar back in.  Every day give yourself something back that you cut out before, but keep the sugar out.

The easiest way I found to start was to eat exceptionally clean and healthy for 3 days. Nothing processed or fried or with sugar. Mostly just greens.

3 days is short enough that anyone can do it, even though it’s still hard. It’s long enough to make a difference though, not just in your mind, but your gut biome.

After that, add back in something you miss that you cut out, but make sure you don’t add any sugar back in. Every day give yourself something back that you cut out before, but keep the sugar out.

comments.body: Get a planner. Actually use it. Finally start therapy. Eat vegetables or fruit at least 1-2 times each day. Yeah, a smoothie counts. Clean your room and bathroom at least once every 2-3 weeks. Forgive yourself but hold yourself accountable when you do, inevitably, screw up.

replies.author: p0k3t0
replies.body:
How does one "start therapy?" Serious question. It's like somebody saying "Buy a car between 18k and 22k. There are like 100 choices, they all look basically the same, and you can't tell if you fucked up until 6 months after you've made the decision.

I mean, seriously. I probably could use some therapy, but I haven't the foggiest idea how to start.
replies.body_html:
How does one "start therapy?" Serious question. It's like somebody saying "Buy a car between 18k and 22k. There are like 100 choices, they all look basically the same, and you can't tell if you fucked up until 6 months after you've made the decision.

I mean, seriously. I probably could use some therapy, but I haven't the foggiest idea how to start.

replies.author: nodnoa
replies.body:
That's a really good question! And I honestly felt the same. It can be overwhelming to get into but here is how I did it. (warning, this is long)

I first tried counseling at college cuz it was a free service provided. I honestly didn't "click" with the 3 counselors I saw and even group therapy wasn't addressing my issues. This mostly boils down to the fact I was struggling with undiagnosed ADHD and the therapy I was in was for anxiety and depression. So treating the symptoms, but not the actual cause.

I graduated and then had a friend unexpectedly pass away. This threw my mental health right down the drain, and a family member I trust suggested I see someone. 

I started by going to my GP, who has known me since I was a teen and she suggested a counselor service. From there I met my counselor and we clicked. She understood my grief issues and helped me finally get diagnosed properly through testing. 

The thing about therapy is that its not for everyone. And not all therapists are the right fit for you. In my experience, you can usually figure this out within one or two sessions. And if it isnt working out with a therapist, you can request to seek someone else. The therapist may even have suggestions for other people in their field who could be a better fit. 

Monetarily I know "shopping around" for a therapist may not be accessible for everyone  so I suggest 1. having a goal in mind for what you want to achieve out of therapy (for me it was coping with loss and ADHD help) 2. research local mental health centers and facilities, a lot have good info on what they specialize in and what insurance they take 

whew ok that was long, but I hope it helps? Good luck and stay well!

comments.author: The_Whale_Biologist
comments.body:
1. Have backup money in the bank, a few months rent
2. Own your car, all that matters is reliability
3. Have good honest relationships with at least 3 other humans
4. Have a physical hobby. Walking Hiking Gym Frisbee Metal Detecting Karate whatever something
5. Profit from your work. If you work hard, make hard work money. Work for yourself to do this if you have to,.
6. Love something. Family God Country Gaming Your Dog Disney whatever something

replies.author: Substantial_Quote

replies.author: colliebluewave
replies.body:
Not op but I naturally compartmentalise super easily. When I was a teen, i was diagnosed with a permanent neurological disability, my single parent mother was diagnosed with cancer, and the only other adult of the family, my gran, was diagnosed with a terminal illness and ironically became suicidal when she realised she was going to die. That was all in the same year. However 99% of the time I was fine. Outside of school I spent most of my free time caring for someone seriously ill or for my siblings. But I never really paused or thought about the implications of this all happening at once, for instance. Generally if I was stressed, I’d take a second to think where I could do anything to resolve this stress, if I could I did it, if I couldn’t I moved on. I did have to tell myself to move on sometimes but I could do it. I decided proactively to talk to my friends about minor stresses, so I had space to talk about things if I wanted to. On the other hand I’m a naturally sunny/happy person so generally if I decided to move on from an emotion/upsetting event I would forget the emotion quite quickly. 

Or for example currently there’s something I have to wait for which is very important for my future. I’m waiting for it but I can’t do anything about it, so instead I’m doing other stuff and not thinking about it. Other people I know with the same wait are thinking about it too much, daydreaming about getting it, or planning for what will happen. I’m comfortable with the alternative options because I know I’m happy in most things/easily pleased, so there’s no point worrying. Instead I’ll get on with work, browse online, tidy up and do housework, do my hobbies. 

Most people naturally compartmentalise. I mean, everyone dies and most people have had existential thoughts. But most of us also realise, yeah we’re going to die one day, and then rarely if ever think about it again beyond making a will. Can’t change it, so shove it to the back of your mind and all the other things going on make you forget about it.

I’m waiting for it but I can’t do anything about it, so instead I’m doing other stuff and not thinking about it. Other people I know with the same wait are thinking about it too much, daydreaming about getting it, or planning for what will happen. I’m comfortable with the alternative options because I know I’m happy in most things/easily pleased, so there’s no point worrying. Instead I’ll get on with work, browse online, tidy up and do housework, do my hobbies.

Most people naturally compartmentalise. I mean, everyone dies and most people have had existential thoughts. But most of us also realise, yeah we’re going to die one day, and then rarely if ever think about it again beyond making a will. Can’t change it, so shove it to the back of your mind and all the other things going on make you forget about it.

comments.author: KieshaLeyba
comments.body:
BE FUCKING BRUTALLY HONEST WITH YOURSELF..

like:

ego me: "you should be a doctor or lawyer"

rational me: Nope - while you'd like the "stature", you'd eventually hate the day-to-day work because you really enjoy your time off and, lets face it, are a little lazy.

replies.author: Hoxeel
replies.body: Careful, this can also end in absolutely fucking hating yourself
replies.body_html: Careful, this can also end in absolutely fucking hating yourself

replies.author: fuckit_sowhat
replies.body:
This is true and I found a fix. 

I like to think of myself as a friend of mine and I think about what things I would say to someone that I care about. For instance:if I look at myself in the mirror and hate how I look I'll tell myself that if another friend was wearing what I was and looked how I looked I'd probably tell them they look cute (because we're all way more judgmental of our looks than those of others). 

If I'm an asshole and feel justified I tell myself the story of what happened and ask questions, "How do you think that other person perceived that? Was there a way you could have handled it better? Should you apologize?" 

It's kind of hard to do, but with practice I've become quite good at being honest with myself regarding both positive and negatives situations and feelings.

It's kind of hard to do, but with practice I've become quite good at being honest with myself regarding both positive and negatives situations and feelings.

replies.author: gliotic
replies.body: I'm the version of you that went through with med school. I mean I don't really *hate* the work but yeah I'd rather just be home playing video games literally all the time.

comments.author: toeofcamell
comments.body:
I sounds corny but try to act “as if”

Talk “as if” you’re confident, act “as if” you belong, act “as if” you deserve success.   If you believe in something hard enough it improves your odds of getting that thing.  

It’s easier to ask forgiveness than ask permission (unless it’s sexual in nature, always ask for permission there), at least that’s what I believe.

replies.author: ScreamingFreakShow
replies.body: This is the meaning behind "Fake it till you make it." You act as if you are something until you truly are.
replies.body_html: This is the meaning behind "Fake it till you make it." You act as if you are something until you truly are.

replies.author: megrimlockk1ng
replies.body:
I feel like this works. 

Everyone thinks I'm massively confident and it's just 'cause I act like it. 

It helped me stand up for myself and others and make some important changes at an old workplace, something I'd never have been able to do before.

comments.author: godofcats
comments.body: Exercise, half-decent diet, 8+ hours of sleep and coffee, lots and lots of coffee.
comments.body_html: Exercise, half-decent diet, 8+ hours of sleep and coffee, lots and lots of coffee.

replies.author: DeathSpiral321
replies.body: I had to cut out the coffee just so I could get some decent sleep.
replies.body_html: I had to cut out the coffee just so I could get some decent sleep.

replies.author: domdomdom7768
replies.body: I absolutely love coffee but had to stop. I never realized after all these years of drinking it that I was super sensitive to caffeine! Thought it was normal to feel your heart beating super fast and slight tightness in the chest. I Could only have 1 medium size mug in the morning and definitely nothing after 3pm. I would have really bad anxiety and when I finally quit 90% of it went away. I still have the occasional moment. Doesn't stop me from sniffing the bags of coffee my husband brings home from traveling.

comments.author: garlicraindrop
comments.body: Keep making choices that fit you, not choices you see everybody else make. I live in a walkable town, so I gave up my car. I hate being interrupted or bothered, so I don't have a cell phone. I don't get that excited over owning things, so long ago I chose a career that pays a lot less but is a lot more satisfying. Today I get in a ton of walking, I never "scroll through my feed," and I love my job. All the decisions looked weird when I made them, but the benefits accumulated with every passing year, and today I'm in late middle age and very happy with my life.
